Le 19 mars 2012 =E0 18:40, nikonguy74 a =E9crit :

> I know one of the fir=
st questions i had was on rel link. I understand the basic premise behind r=
el attributes(to provide a general documentation for how to interact with t=
he link provider). The question is what would you see if you go to the rel =
link? Is it something a person is suppose to interact with (say to get docu=
mentation for new links added to a specific response) or something code can=
 interact with to determine what it needs to do? Unfortunately in the book =
they don't give an example of what a "rel" page would look like. For exampl=
e the link:
> <link rel=3D"http://relations.restbucks.com/payment"
> href:=
=3D"http://restbucks.com/payment/1234" />
> 
> If you typed in "http://rela=
tions.restbucks.com/payment" into your web browser what would you see? 
> 
=
Typically, an HTTP 404 error message. 
The values of such rel attributes do=
 not need to be dereferencable. They are used as mere names for identifying=
 the nature of the link. 
For added fun, you can optionally make them deref=
erencable, providing for instance a human readable documentation about the =
semantic of that particular type of link, or whatever suits you, but this i=
sn't required.  

Best,

Philippe Mougin
--Apple-Mail=_36AD1690-AABF-41C0-AF94-D42E6DFD73C3
